dt: {bc}to gather from a number of sources
{bc}to accept or adopt for the purpose of assisting
{bc}to accept or adopt as one's own

dt.t: {it}took up{/it} the life of a farmer

dt: {bc}to enter upon (something, such as a business, hobby, or subject of study)
{bc}to proceed to consider or deal with

dt.t: {it}take up{/it} one problem at a time
the meeting was {it}taken up{/it} with old business

dt: {bc}to respond favorably to (a person offering a bet, challenge, proposal, etc.)
{bc}to begin again or take over from another

dt.t: we must {it}take{/it} the good work {it}up{/it} again

dt: {bc}to make a beginning where another has left off
{bc}to engage vigorously in a defense or dispute
{bc}to begin to associate or consort with

shortdef: to gather from a number of sources

dt: {bc}to fight in defense or support of (someone or something)

dt.t: She {it}took up the cudgels for{/it} women's rights.

shortdef: to fight in defense or support of (someone or something)

dt: {bc}to show that one is willing and ready to fight, argue, or compete with someone or to do something that is difficult but necessary {bc}to accept or respond to a challenge

dt.t: The time has come for Congress to {it}pick up the gauntlet{/it} and do something about this problem.

shortdef: to show that one is willing and ready to fight, argue, or compete with someone or to do something that is difficult but necessary : to accept or respond to a challenge

dt: {bc}to provide or do something that is missing or not getting done

dt.t: The manager has to {it}take up the slack{/it} when employees don't do their jobs correctly.
When he didn't get the pay raise he was expecting, he had to take another job to {it}pick up the slack{/it} for more money.

shortdef: to provide or do something that is missing or not getting done

dt: {bc}to pick up weapons and become ready to fight

dt.t: They {it}took up arms{/it} to defend their city.
The rebels are {it}taking up arms{/it} against their own government.

shortdef: to pick up weapons and become ready to fight

dt.t: Birds have {it}taken up residence{/it} in the barn.
